awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Sociopolitical Development and STEM Motivation in African American Youth
awd_abstract_narration:
Racial disparities in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) have persisted for decades. This project assesses African American students' awareness of racial inequities and how such awareness is related to students' STEM motivation through three broad aims: (1) to investigate changes in students' science and math motivation as they transition to high school; (2) to measure changes in youth's knowledge of racial inequities across the high school transition and whether such knowledge is related to changes in STEM course-taking; and (3) to examine the influences of African American parents' race-related experiences and beliefs on their socialization of their children and on their children's STEM motivation. In addition to contributing to scientific theory regarding racial inequalities, motivation, and achievement outcomes, the study has the potential to inform intervention efforts that would target adolescents' and parents' knowledge of racial inequities and ways that families might foster youth's success in STEM domains. Immediate impacts include training of undergraduate and graduate students from underrepresented backgrounds and creation of an intergroup dialogue program for students and parents aimed at increasing their race-related academic consciousness.

Participants are 380 African American youth and their parents and teachers who have already participated annually in this STEM-focused research project during the youth's middle school years. In this new stage of the project, students, parents, and teachers will complete surveys when youth are in Grades 9 and 10. Key hypotheses to be evaluated are (1) science and math motivation will be strongest among youth who already in middle school held an awareness of inequities, and whose motivational beliefs emphasize agency and efficacy; (2) students' awareness of racial achievement gaps will increase over time, and system-blame attributions (e.g., attributing achievement gaps to teacher bias) will lead to greater STEM persistence and success; (3) parents' knowledge of racial inequality will be positively associated with racial pride socialization and preparation of their children for discrimination; and (4) parents' racial socialization, homework monitoring, school involvement, and encouragement of youth's extracurricular STEM activities will be positively associated with youth's STEM success.  We will test these hypotheses using latent growth curve modeling, assessing change over time and ways in which earlier measures (e.g., students' and parents' awareness of achievement gaps when youth were in middle school) predict change in parents' socializing behaviors and students' STEM motivation and success. These results will inform our intergroup dialogue program, which will be designed with the collaboration of consultants at the University of Michigan and California State University.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

The Parenting for STEM Success in African American Students project acknowledges the important role that parents play in the development of motivation and achievement for youth in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). The study further emphasized the influence of African American parents’ race-related experiences and beliefs in shaping their STEM-related socialization strategies. We posit that parents’ beliefs about the realities of being Black in the United States inform their views about technical fields such as math and science, areas where African American students are especially likely to underperform. To that end, the study examined whether African American parents’ experiences with racial discrimination, awareness of racial academic stereotypes and racial inequalities, and their beliefs about the origins of racial achievement gaps influence the ways in which they support their children’s development in STEM courses as youth move through middle and high school. We expect that the results will be used to develop interventions for African American families that will encourage greater participation in advanced STEM coursework and the likelihood that African American students will aspire to STEM-related careers.

Students and parents had previously participated annually through the middle school years, grades 6 to 8. In this project, youth were followed into high school, completing surveys each year in grades 9 through 11. The high school years are critical in shaping decisions about future educational and employment trajectories, and are also a time when adolescents are rapidly developing understanding of race and inequality and when parents begin to talk about race more openly with their children. One parent and science and math teachers also participated in each year of the study. Families were living in one of three low-income, racially diverse school districts.

Our results demonstrate the sometimes subtle ways that awareness of racial inequality influences the academic outcomes of African American students. For example, adolescents’ perceptions that race achievement gaps are primarily due to characteristics of individual students such as race differences in motivation were negatively associated with their math, science, and English achievement as well as their reports of academic preparation. 

Our results also underscore the critical role that parents play as filters of the racialized society in which we live. The general pattern of results suggests that parents’ race-related beliefs (e.g., stereotype endorsement, beliefs about the reasons underlying racial achievement gaps, and knowledge about racial inequalities) influence how they talk to their children about race and how they support their children’s STEM learning. This racial socialization and more general STEM socialization on the part of parents was, in turn, associated with achievement outcomes for the students. Not surprisingly, parents’ conversations with their adolescents about racial barriers were positively associated with youths’ awareness of racism, and parents’ negative messages about the abilities of Black people were related to youths’ perceptions that race achievement gaps are due to individual characteristics of students.

The broader impacts of the project lie primarily in the implications of the findings for NSF’s aim of broadening participation of underrepresented minority students in STEM, the training of students from marginalized backgrounds (i.e., underrepresented minority and immigrant students), and the dissemination of results at national conferences and to local partner organizations. One of the most important aspects of the project has been the development of rich relationships with local school personnel. We have shared our expertise with each participating school to address pressing issues that they are facing. These activities include workshops for teachers on reducing racial disparities in disciplinary action, panels for students on how to prepare to go to college, and afterschool activities for students with behavior problems. Results of the project have been shared with parents and teachers.
